I also wanted to draw attention to the concern we have about the presence of naval traffic throughout the region, the risk that it represents, also for the European Union, and the shocking evidence of its presence in Guinea-Bissau.
Also, I would like to appeal in this context to the relationship with Cabo Verde.

We establish a special partnership with Cabo Verde. Cabo Verde has close relations with Guinea-Bissau, great knowledge, but it is also very vulnerable. This is also essential for our own European security.
Therefore, it is also very important in this context to intensify the special partnership with Cape Verde.
Madam President, dear colleagues, I would like first of all to thank everyone for their work.

The three lines defined in the Green Paper – concentration, interconnection and cooperation – can provide solutions to some obstacles to the smooth development of the Union, namely the negative effects associated with the

Concentration of economic activity in areas of inequality in terms of access to markets and services resulting from distance and divisions imposed by both member state borders, especially those that are more disadvantaged, as well as between regions.
Therefore, we should promote the improvement of synergies between these policies with methods for assessing their territorial impact.

Therefore, I have always defended the definition of additional quality indicators with the aim of improving the understanding and implementation of land policies taking into account different territorial specificities.
Therefore, the PIB continues to be the only eligibility criterion for receiving support from structural funds.

Therefore, the definition of complementary indicators and the implementation of territorial assessments should not lead to more bureaucracy or delays, but rather to simplifying the application of new policies and support actions for territorial cohesion.
The fifth report (Kallari) refers specifically to transitional regions between convergence and competitiveness and employment areas.
It is necessary to pay attention that these regions need a clearer statute with more security and stability for their development.

Ladies and gentlemen, in the context of this major debate on territorial cohesion and the future of economic and social cohesion policy, I cannot fail to mention the very specific problem of ultra-peripheral regions.

Geographic regions that have been shaped by and persistently feature certain geographical factors exhibit significant economic and social vulnerability, particularly in light of the current international crisis we are experiencing.
I would like to appeal to the European Commission and especially to Commissioner Hubner to pay very special attention to the effects of the current crisis in the outermost regions.

An evaluation of these effects in each one of the outermost regions, namely in tourism, construction and in the increase of unemployment, would be important in order to allow a specific European response for these regions.

I therefore challenge the European Commission to prepare a European response to the crisis for the outermost regions that goes beyond the measures already announced within the framework of the Economic and Social Cohesion Policy for the general European regions.
A European response to the crisis for the regions.

In response to the global financial crisis, the European Economic Recovery Plan refers to the cohesion policy, which significantly contributes to public investment by Member States and regions, which should act as a form of recovery from the current crisis.
Adopt specific actions in priority areas of the Lisbon strategy to achieve growth and employment.
All activated instruments aim to achieve this purpose and accelerate the achievement of results.

In that sense, the extension of the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and the speeding up of the European Social Fund have a particular responsibility to respond to the multiple situations of social and economic emergency that lack support.
I am sure that, as in the past, their action will be more effective when it is more complementary with their actions and scope.

However, as it was not foreseen that new funds or new lines of action on the ground would be created, it is particularly important that the European Social Fund should be used to its full potential in the fight against unemployment and the rapid increase in competitiveness in the European economy resulting from the current financial crisis and economic contraction.

I would like to emphasize that simplification has repeatedly been identified by the R&D Committee as essential for improving the management and implementation of structural funds, just as the European Commission is now proposing.
Urgent action was taken in this matter, however, and when adopting this regulatory package, they took it into account, and this cause never shied away from assuming its political responsibilities.

Therefore, despite many different views that the particularity of the moment suggests, there are also guarantees of the certainty of the process and the real benefit it brings to citizens. We should therefore not hesitate to present new proposals and changes at this time.
However, we must be alert to the need to start already the evaluation process of this fund with a view to a complementary review as soon as possible. Thank you.
The crisis, among other things, allowed to highlight the strong imbalances between the countries of the euro area, perhaps the main
Conclusion of the EEA report. But above all, the extreme vulnerability of countries which belong to the European Union but do not belong to the euro area.

Therefore, it is absolutely essential that the European Union should reinforce its available resources to support crisis situations in the balance-of-payments area, which is why we welcome the increase from EUR 12 billion to EUR 25 billion and later to EUR 50 billion in necessary resources.
However, it is more important to attack the root causes of problems rather than just their most evident manifestations.
Today, Europe as a whole and the euro area have to reinterpret the meaning of European solidarity and the objectives of cohesion and real convergence.
It is necessary to examine horizontal European policies in this light, but it is also necessary to revisit new financing instruments such as Eurobonds.
Financial assistance to the payment balance is necessary but it is far from being sufficient to ensure the sustainability of the European project and the European single currency.
We are in an unprecedented crisis.

It was not the time to discuss internally how we should organize ourselves; therefore, my votes are in favor of quickly adopting the Treaty of Lisbon so that we can face the global scene united and solidary as Europeans.

In relation to the economic crisis, in the report I was the author of which this Parliament approved by a large majority, it admitted that the recovery plan presented by the Commission at that time was not sufficient.
Today we have no certainty that it is not sufficient.
A crisis that started as a financial one, affecting the real economy, employment and social affairs.
It is not sufficient and it is focused.

Every crisis presents an opportunity. This is the opportunity for the Commission to respond to the real problems of Europeans through serious financial regulation, not with more lenient and piecemeal measures that have been proposed.
How is it possible that this is ongoing? Not on individual national plans but on a true European initiative, not through dispersed means but focusing on the real challenge that I employ.

In every crisis there is an opportunity. This is the opportunity for the Commission and Europe to respond to the real problems of European citizens, and I hope that this will happen through a new approach to the recovery plan for the economy.

Dear Mr President, dear colleagues, I just wanted to express – not only on behalf of the PPE as has already been done by many other Members, but particularly on behalf of the Portuguese Members of the PPE Group – our great satisfaction with the result of the referendum in Ireland.
We argue that this reinforces clearly the prospects of development and evolution of the European Union, creating conditions for a new stage.

We would now like to compliment all those who contributed to the Treaty of Lisbon, particularly the Commission and the Vice President here present, as well as naturally the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union.

The role played by this institution was very important, which is why we want to say that it is with great regret that despite all these vice-presidencies and still maintaining our expectations regarding the position of the Czech Republic, it will be with great pleasure that the Portuguese will see the name of their capital Lapa tied.

A decisive step in the evolution of the European Union. I would also like to say that we can compare this perspective with another flag, which will always be a flag for Portuguese Members of the PPE too, which is the flag of national parliaments.
We contend that this Treaty of Lisbon represents a decisive step towards incorporating national parliaments into European democracy.
Therefore, we consider that this dimension, which is the most important aspect of democracy, is the representative dimension, not the electoral dimension, as we often hear in this House.

The fundamental and essential principle of democracy is representation, not direct voting. The Treaty of Lisbon is also a major step towards increasing the participation of national representative democracies in the European process.
Therefore, we are very satisfied with this decision by the Dutch people.

A brief intervention to welcome the historic and resounding result of the referendum in Ireland and to highlight the decisive role that Fine Gaelle and its leader and next Taoiseach of Ireland, Enda Kenny, played in leading this process.
The process in which it became clear that there was a strong need to bring the European Union much closer to its citizens.
They are we, all of us, the main recipients of all Union action.
It is essential that everyone be aware of the impact and benefits that Europe has daily in our lives.
Europe is our vital space.
What is good for Europe is good for each member state, it is good for their citizens.
It is surely the case of the Treaty of Lisbon.
With this treaty it becomes much more evident that one can be simultaneously a proud and committed national citizen and an assiduous defender of the European project.

The European Union, after having engaged in an excessively lengthy debate on its organisation and functioning, can now concentrate much more, using brand new and far more effective tools, on the real problems that Europeans face: competitiveness, growth, and employment.
I conclude, Mr President, Mrs Minister, with a proposal aimed at future generations.

Considering the lack of information on the values, competences, objectives and mode of functioning of the European Union, the European Parliament should propose, at the end of compulsory education in each Member State, a new European Studies curricula of an optional nature.
Objectively, truly, and concretely, European young people will learn what our principles are, who we are, what we do, and where we want to go.

It is through knowledge from an early age that young people will understand the potential and enormous usefulness of European identity throughout their lives in this single project of voluntary sovereignty at a continental scale.
Thank you Mr President, Mr Barroso, for this first debate on what this new political control instrument signifies for the progress and development of parliamentary democracy in Europe.
Are European citizens, through their representatives, gaining anything?

Considering recent developments in Irish referendum, Polish ratification, and the latest statements by the Czech President, I would like to ask what assessment you make on the process of the Treaty of Lisbon entering into force?
There has been due diligence by the President of the Commission.
The forecast for the entry into force of the treaty and, on the other hand, to know if at this moment, based on that forecast, the Commission
Made some transitionary acts already from the Treaty of Nice to the Treaty of Lisbon? Or is it still in an expectation phase, so to speak – in other words, in a phase of waiting to see?
Mr President of the Commission, having heard that, I would like to know the following: at this stage, when everyone is waiting for the formation of the Commission, what is your perspective?
Will there be a moment when the Czech Republic will finally ratify it, with a management commission, or will they proceed with the appointment of the new commissioners?

It is essential that the primary objective of establishing a European External Action Service solidify the European institutions' efforts, ensuring the creation of an effective service capable of articulating, formulating, and implementing a European response to the present international challenges.
It should still represent more than the parts that constitute it; it should be a value added relatively to the current efforts of the Member States and the European Union.
In that sense, it seems essential to me that what makes the Union specific should be at the center of this new reality, and that particularity is the Community method.
It is for this reason that I give my full support to the Brok report, which defends and saves a strict articulation between the Commission and the future service.

To create this purpose to align two aspects: the importance of closer coordination between the President of the Commission and the High Representative (also Vice-President of the Commission) to ensure its efficiency and proper functioning.
Finally, there is a need for an alliance between Parliament and the Commission to combat the intergovernmental drift that is emerging, which could compromise the effective functioning of the service.

The European Parliament must therefore be vigilant and ensure that the European External Action Service will become a centre of excellence, representing the best competencies in external policy matters.
Thank you Mr President, thank you Commissioner. I would first of all like to underline the importance of this question put forward by Mr Glorandi because it is an issue of basic justice.

We all perfectly well know that in a pandemic situation of flu there will be those countries in the South that will suffer more from this problem and with the consequences of the virus spreading, rather than the Northern countries.

We watch in total passivity as millions of citizens and citizens die as a result of pandemics that have already been eradicated or treated in the countries of the North – an immense list: malaria, dengue, yellow fever, tuberculosis.
We have no limits for this list and we watch passively as this problem occurs.

We use southern countries as actual suppliers of free samples of new virus strains in order to improve treatment in northern countries but we do not get an effective response to these problems. Therefore I would like to add some more questions to those that were put forward.
We want to actually address this problem as a public health issue or as a business issue.
Because if we treat it as a public health problem, we have to ensure equal access to treatment in all regions of the world, and for that reason, efforts have to be more effective.
On the other hand, I would like to ask you – and I hope it is not the case – if we are waiting for the vaccine stocks in Europe to eventually run out?
The secondary effects reveal themselves to be so negative in this regard that we have started, unexpectedly, to send the necessary vaccines to the southern countries.

And lastly, I would just like to ask if the European Union, if we Europeans, if the Commission is comfortable with a system or with a model where the North deals with pandemics through a prevention model, and in the South it deals with them as palliatives or only with leftovers?

Thank you Mr President. I would like first of all to express my full support on the issue raised by Mr Royer and above all to highlight the fundamental question, the political question of principle which is at stake in this matter, which specifically relates to the joint programming of research.

What happened regarding the joint programming on neurodegenerative diseases, and specifically Alzheimer's disease, was that in the process, the rules changed. We stopped having a report and moved to a resolution, which therefore eliminated our ability to take part in decision-making on this matter. We stopped being elected and became consultants.
Therefore, I would like to know if at least what we recommend will be taken into consideration or not.
The programming of research activities, regardless of its subject matter, is a political choice, not a technical one. In this sense, the role of Parliament should be valued and strengthened.
Defining priorities as political means that they should be prioritized, transparent, and democratic.
What happened with the process regarding the joint decision and the joint programming of research on Alzheimer's disease is a process that should not be repeated, and if it is repeated,
Please repeat with timing, I hope that the last thing that may happen to us is that our decisions and recommendations are not taken into account by the Council.
In the last month, in particular, European regions have been particularly evident.
The European Week of Regions and Cities has consolidated the position of regions as a fundamental part of the solution in Europe's response to global challenges.
If so concluded, leaving no room for doubt, President Barroso, Commissioner Sammecky and the hundreds of debates that took place.

Also at a more specific level, the holding of the important meeting of the Conference of Presidents of the European regions, which counted for the first time with the participation of Members of the European Parliament, constitutes a milestone in regional policy in favor of European construction.
Global challenges and European responses constitute an excellent opportunity for a new strategy for the EU.

These regions, such as the Azores, where the permanent constraints that everyone is used to hearing talked about, present a set of potentialities that clearly offer opportunities to achieve our progress and give a clear advantage to Europe in new essential domains for answering global challenges.

Therefore, does the President of the Commission not think it appropriate to put an end to this Portuguese coup d'état, which the Commission's own document indicates was being prepared while we, as Members of Parliament and European citizens, were debating the ratification of the Treaty of Lisbon and its importance in maintaining territorial cohesion?
I would like to start by thanking the rapporteurs, namely Mr Martin and also Mr Corbet, for their work. As a member of the PPE Group, I basically agree with the changes proposed to the system.
I would like primarily to highlight the point that seems important to me here tonight and which was not brought forward this evening, namely the role of national parliaments.
The strengthening of the European Parliament is undoubtedly due to this regime and the Treaty of Lisbon, but European democracy also results from the link with national parliaments.
And what this regime has proposed now is precisely to create these two democratic legacies, to reinforce democracy.

On the one hand, democracy resulting from the European Parliament's own instruments, its control mechanisms, its legislative capacity, and on the other hand, democratic cooperation between national parliaments through different instruments.
And that is why I am here, let's say, in full alignment with the proposals made.
Do you disagree with Mr Duff that we should leave the introduction of mechanisms for relations with national parliaments until later?
What can we do already under the light of the Treaty of Lisbon? And that is very important.
I would also like to say that I support the proposal by my colleagues Sáry and Brok regarding representation in the COSAC, and finally, that I am
We entirely agree with Mr Brok and other colleagues on the primacy of Parliament and its Members in relation to the services of Parliament.
Thank you Mr President, Mrs President, Commissioner, colleagues. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on her work on this report and her intervention earlier.
This new microfinance instrument will allow the concession of microcredit to small companies and individuals who lost their jobs and want to create their own business and their own job.
This is very important in a period when it is expected that the economic crisis will result in the loss of three million and a half jobs in the European Union alone.

As a consequence of the economic expansion, banks stopped granting loans for job creation and business start-ups, making access to credit more difficult at a time when it should have been more accessible.
This new microfinance facility will counteract the current trend of restricting access to credit, facilitating the acquisition of necessary funds for launching new businesses and creating new jobs.
The European Commission proposal aims to reallocate €100 million from the Progress programme budget for this financing instrument.
We cannot agree with this proposal.
The financial and economic crisis is equally a social crisis.
Thus, the redirection of resources from progress towards more vulnerable groups is not necessarily the most appropriate solution.
Therefore, there is support for the creation of a separate budget line to fund this instrument as well as an increase in the allocation by 150 million euros.

We also agree that it is necessary to clarify in the legislation itself that the reference group consists of vulnerable groups who have difficulty entering or re-entering the labor market and face the threat of social exclusion.
Thus, the reference to specific groups should be deleted.
Finally, if we encourage those who have financial support to also receive proper training,

Thank you Mr President. I would like to start by congratulating the Swedish Presidency and in particular Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt on behalf of the PPE Group and the Portuguese delegation of the PPE Group.
The balance of the Swedish Presidency has been almost entirely successful, essentially in four key areas.
The first in the institutional area is the Swedish Presidency's contribution to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon and the very successful election of the President of the Commission.

The English translation of the provided Portuguese speech is as follows:
'For specifically all the issues related to ratification associated with the ratification process, it was extremely professional and at the level one expects from the best practices in the European Union.'
Of course, for a country like Portugal, which had a decisive role in the adoption of the Treaty of Lisbon, this contribution from the Swedish Presidency is invaluable.
A second point is the climate agenda where naturally the work of the commission was also extremely important.
We should say that, from my point of view and from the point of view of many Members of the PPE Group, it is in the area of climate change that the European Union has had more success.
It is facing a real global battle, which is due to the efforts made by both the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, the Commission Presidency.
We consider this balance also very positive.
A third point is the financial regulation point, which especially with this last Council gave a step that we consider decisive and which can have a very big impact on the exit from the crisis.
Therefore, I also wanted to give you credit for having achieved an agreement in that area.
Finally, I have one word on an area that personally concerns me greatly, which is the Stockholm Programme area – justice, freedom and security.

I accompanied the process, both in the tempering stage and especially after the DAIA process. I consider this programme absolutely essential and I would like to offer my compliments to the Swedish Presidency and to Prime Minister Fato for that purpose.

For the recognition of professional qualifications, it was consolidated in a single legislative act – as you know – fifteen directives, which originated various problems in its practical application in the different Member States.

The difficulties are known and the Commission should inventory the critical points and carry out an analysis of the problematic areas that arise in the application of this important internal market instrument.
Protectionism in various forms constitutes an obstacle not only to the free movement of people but also to the internal market.
We should try to identify the weak spots so that the effectiveness of the directive is not undermined by distrust.
The European Union is not asked to do what the Member States should do, but there is an effort to facilitate implementation that helps to dismantle professional corporatism.
Improvement of application of this directive should involve disclosure of recognition of qualifications in the EER network by the incentive of
Common platforms, implementation of effective contact points, and not less important, it will provide articulation of this directive with the Services Directive.
Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is urgent that we promote a debate on the EU budget and how it can be made more sustainable and transparent in future.

The post-2013 financial framework should be constructed on the basis of solidarity and territorial cohesion – values that are crucial for regions such as Madeira, which face permanent difficulties and require permanent support.
I would like to share with you some ideas that I believe should always be present when thinking and building cohesion policy.

The Commission has repeatedly referred to some aspects that seem essential to me, such as the need for greater flexibility, simplicity, efficiency, and more guidance on achieving results in defining and implementing this policy.
But there are issues that give me some concern, especially considering the needs of the outermost regions.
In this matter, allow me three brief notes. Firstly, the current approach in terms of regions must prevail over alternative approaches, such as added value sectors, for example.

A reorientation like this could endanger Objective 2, which currently benefits roughly two-thirds of European regions, in addition to potentially being counter-productive in economically preferred regions with significant competitive advantages. Secondly, it seems to me that maintaining the proximity criterion in cohesion policy is vital.

It should continue to privilege itself an allocation and management of structural funds on a regional perspective and not a national or even centralized perspective at European level. Thirdly and lastly but no less importantly I would like to recall and underscore Article 349.
349th Treaty of Lisbon provides for special treatment of ultra-peripheral regions in relation to access to structural funds, precisely because of their economic and social situation.
Worsened by conditionalism and unique characteristics of a given period, which manifest in constant difficulties, thereby requiring the claimed permanent assistance.
The English translation of the provided Portuguese speech is: 'Mr President, what we witnessed in Copenhagen was several steps backwards.'

It is true that Copenhagen mobilized more Heads of State than Kyoto, but it also wanted more divisions, and as a result, what happened was that we went from having a situation where everyone was on their own, where each state could define its own goals, and even above all in a voluntary system.
The English translation of the provided Portuguese speech is: 'Referring to a two degree centigrade target or financing targets without any clarification can also not serve as a basis.'
Therefore, what I think is that we have to act in terms of the future, and acting in terms of the future is to stop talking about action and start taking action.
The European Union has always wanted to be a leader, it has always affirmed that.
But when we went to Copenhagen, it turned out that they hesitated, neither defining nor defending the goals which here they affirmed would be their goals and of which they did not deviate.
Therefore, what I ask is whether in the future we will not be more just if we continue to allow the poor to pay the highest price for this failure and for the decisions made over them?
Thank you very much, Mr President. I wanted to denounce here what is happening in Portugal at this moment, where it is clear that social communication
Brought to light a government plan to control the press, to control television stations, to control radio stations – which puts at risk freedom of expression.
This week, a well-known journalist, Mario Cresspo, saw his article censored because it also suggested or appeared to suggest the first minister.

Despite this, Prime Minister José Sócrates has to provide substantial explanations to the country, he has to explain that he is not dominating, controlling, censoring freedom of expression in Portugal.

Portugal is no longer a state governed by the rule of law; it is a state governed by formal law, where the Prime Minister restricts himself to formalities, procedures, and formalisms and does not want to provide substantial explanations.
We want a material state for Portugal.

The Green Paper on the reform of common fisheries policy, whose rapporteur is my colleague Mr Patrício Neves, is an unique opportunity for a debate about an sector that assumes great importance in the balance of local development in ultra-peripheral regions.

Madama accompanies with particular interest the discussion in progress and considers it imperative that an differentiation between artisanal and industrial fleets be proposed, which should negotiate different fishing regimes.
It is essential to uphold a principle of positive discrimination in limiting access to territorial waters within the exclusive economic zone to only local artisanal fishing fleets.
In Madeira, it is a priority to support the modernisation of vessels as well as ensuring the conservation of an extensive range of species in the long term.
We can thus avoid unsustainable situations for economic, environmental and social balance.
In conclusion, we will strive for permanent support for fisheries in outermost regions rather than temporary ones.
This report on FEDER aims to broaden the scope of interventions in the housing sector in support of disadvantaged communities in our Member States.
Until now, this support has only been available to marginalized communities living in urban areas of the new Member States.
In other words, since the vast majority of these communities live in rural and farm areas, they could not benefit from support to replace substandard housing.
The focus is on how to eradicate a vaccine and give other Member States and their regions greater opportunities in mitigation policy for the specific difficulties of these communities.
I also welcome equality of treatment for all Member States, since marginalized communities with support and integration needs deserve our concern regardless of which Member State they belong to.

In conclusion, this important report on the fight against poverty and for human dignity also achieves its rapid support in the area of economic governance, responding in a timely manner to the crisis that affects us.

Thank you Mr President, Commissioner. Let me start by acknowledging the role of the rapporteur, Mr Van Rompuy, for his work in seeking consensus on this matter and also for his openness to incorporating other contributions into his report.
Tomorrow we will be voting on amendments to the FEDER regulation that are particularly important for what are known as the old Member States and also for Portugal.

These changes will allow the extension of the use of the FEDER in the housing sector for the benefit of marginalized communities, since currently this fund can only be allocated to urban development operations.

The amendments I tabled in conjunction with other colleagues and which were approved by a large majority in the Committee on Regional Development will allow the old Member States, and not just the new ones, as originally proposed, to also benefit from this financing opportunity.
With this, I tried to avoid creating a precedent that I consider dangerous and which would exclude all the old Member States from this and probably other additional uses of Community aid.
What would not make sense in any way, given that housing problems, especially among marginalized communities, exist both in new and old EU member states.
I take this opportunity to reiterate that the antiquity of EU membership should not be a criterion for allocating structural funds and that this criterion must be abolished.

Negotiation on post-2013 cohesion policy should be based on solidarity, aiming at territorial cohesion, and should aim to reward rather than penalise regions that have shown exemplary use of EU assistance.
I would like, at this moment, primarily to emphasize to the Commission and to the President of the Commission how they worked with this Parliament over these months of negotiation.
There is no worldwide body with executive and legislative initiative that is subject to presenting its President with a programme before Parliament for hearing by all groups.

Parliamentarians – a voting by absolute majority expressiva; bringing here all the Commissioners to be heard one by one with their own programme, with three or four hours of direct questions, direct questions with answers.

Someone who accepted to negotiate with Parliament an agreement framework, in which they accepted, first and foremost, to justify and empower the powers of Parliament in the field of legislative initiative.

The speaker accepted the principle of full information access in both legislative and political action and international negotiations, as well as taking Parliament's opinion into account regarding the Commissioners and their restructuring.
This means, once and for all, from my point of view, that the Commission has proved since July until now that it is willing to have a close relationship with Parliament, and that it is ready
The alliance between the Treaty of Lisbon and the Community method, as referred to by Mr Saryusz-Wolski, the alliance between Parliament and the Commission - this is what we have achieved.
Therefore, the Commission and the Framework Agreement deserve the full support of the PPE Group.
Five years after the Orange Revolution, Ukrainians appear to look at this period as a missed opportunity.
And the blame is not just on its political elites.
It is true that they were excessively consumed in wars of power and influence.
Many reforms remained pending, many did not even make it onto the paper.
It is inconceivable that in any democracy the electoral laws should be altered between the two rounds of an election.
It does not signify who proposed them, who voted for them or who promoted them.
And translates the intentions little lovable and recommended in his agenda.
A lot has to change regarding the lack of independence of the judicial power, which is subject to excessive influence not only from the political power but also from economic agents.
Without a free and independent justice system, there is no rule of law, human rights are not guaranteed, foreign investment is not possible, and progress is not possible.
But the blame for this disillusionment also rests heavily on this Parliament and essentially in many Member States.
I would like us, for a moment, to put ourselves in the shoes of a citizen of a European country that, due to historical circumstances, has not yet joined the European Union.
We expect from the Union.
Solidarity.

However, many chancelleries with the exclusive concern not to upset and offend Moscow used and abused the ongoing internal fights in Ukraine to avoid stating unambiguously that Ukraine is an independent and sovereign country.
Ukraine can aspire in the future to be a member of the European Union if it has the freely expressed will of its majority and meets the criteria established.
Inland waterways offer the only possibility of access in coastal areas, and their operating conditions are dictated by the size of passenger and cargo flows.

There are areas in Europe where the abundance of these fires is perceptible for many air operators, attracting competition and lower transport prices, thus improving accessibility. Others exist, such as Azores, where these fires are still reduced, not being attractive or interesting for operators.

As a result, air fares are higher, which hampers the mobility of people and is an obstacle to attracting tourists who would enable its huge potential for economic development and diversification to flourish and be constructed.
This framework is particularly penalizing in times of crisis such as the one we are experiencing.

Therefore, temporary support that boosts the increase in traffic so that the market can start functioning, also sharing these high potential tourist regions with the objectives of trans-European networks in bringing Europe's peripheries closer together.
The President spoke today in this Chamber with a voice laden with consternation for those who lived and witnessed personally the tragedy that occurred last Saturday in Aveiro.

My words are obviously those of solidarity with the pain and distress felt by the families of the victims of this tragedy, which at this moment has reached 42, to whom I offer my deepest condolences for their losses.

The true dimension of this disaster is still yet to be revealed as the search and rescue teams who have been working tirelessly since Saturday in an aerial effort which I welcome begin to reach the more isolated populations.
It is feared that the number of victims could increase.
The scenario is one of widespread destruction with major damage to buildings, roads and bridges and essential services such as water supply and electricity.
About 600 people have been evacuated who lost their homes and belongings.
The economic and social impact of this catastrophe prevents people from returning to a normal life course.
But now we need to look forward.
I also need to send a message of solidarity, hope, and confidence to people.
It is necessary to help, and it is in this chapter that the European Union and Parliament have a say. They are fundamental in the process of mobilizing the Solidarity Fund.
We must act quickly when we are called upon to intervene, because we cannot ask people to wait, especially when they need us most.

I appeal to the Commission and its President, Mr Barroso, especially to Commissioner responsible for regional development, Ms Wallström, and I welcome her initiative to visit Madeira within the shortest possible timeframe.
Please also be an ambassador for this message of hope, help and support for reconstruction, because now is the time to rebuild what nature has unfortunately and once again taken away.
But be sure we will do it, because as the late Mr. Madares used to say, the Portuguese people are humble, modest, and brave.
It is the people who, with their hard work, have tilled the land. Hero of labor in the Montsenyage.
Madera will honor its history and in the face of work will struggle and achieve well-being and glory.
We begin this plenary session with a minute of silence.

It was a minute of silence with two meanings: one of solidarity with the victims of this catastrophe that struck Madeira and their families, and a sense of homage to all those workers and workers who have provided assistance to those victims in an unwavering manner.
A minute of silence should make us reflect and should also pave the way for a reflection that goes beyond what we are doing here.
What we came from Madeira is a phenomenon that will have to repeat itself over and over again.
The English translation of the provided Portuguese speech is: 'Climate change makes extreme weather phenomena repeat, and we have to respond to them.'
We cannot avoid natural disasters, but we should not be resigned to the fact that they always have such devastating effects on people's lives.
Therefore, we should strive for planning and order policies that are directed to the public good.

The most important thing, however, Mr President, is that the European Commission, the European Parliament and the European institutions must be capable of responding urgently to an urgent situation, and for this they need the necessary financial resources and the political will required.
A homenagem de solidariedade para com os familiares e amigos das vítimas dos trágicos acontecimentos de sábado na Ilha da Madeira.
As a Portuguese-Spanish and European, I cannot help but commend Parliament and the Union for their active solidarity with the Autonomous Region of Madeira and its people.

It is in the regions that the presence of the Union needs to be meaningful, and it is precisely at this time, when its solidarity is most necessary, that it is also more important than ever for it to be meaningful.

Also, I want to express my solidarity with the Madeirans and urge the European institutions, particularly the Commission, to unblock all available resources and make every effort to provide assistance.
It would also be worth noting that when there is a disaster of this type, it is much more difficult to address its consequences when it occurs in poor countries and in poor regions.

But in the case of Madeira, we also have to consider that the economic base of Madeira is directly affected by the fact of depending on tourism. This has a double consequence when its natural beauties, its accessibilities, and its quality of life are all destroyed.
Therefore, there is actually a different situation when we have problems of this gravity in poor countries and in poor regions, and particularly in mountainous and tourist areas, such as Madeira.
Therefore, it is essential that all the adaptations which were foreseen, requested and remembered here regarding the Solidarity Fund, do not wait any longer.

They should come into force immediately, because unfortunately, due to climate change and these processes, they will unfortunately be repeated, especially in the poorest regions of Europe, which are those that experience torrential rainfall in terms of water and extreme drought during summer. Thank you once again, Mr President.
We are talking about the European-scale energy system reinvention through investment in low-carbon technologies.
I think it is one of the very important challenges, as it is referred to in the communication that has been made.
It is one of the central challenges we have to face, but there is no clarification here, which is why it is important to address these issues and seek clarification.
It seems that there is not just a lack of clarification on funding but also a lack of political clarification.
Energy efficiency, carbon capture, nuclear energy, biofuels, solar energy, including energy efficiency as the cheapest way to reduce emissions.
I find it hard to believe that there are other, much cheaper ways to reduce CO2 emissions which are not even mentioned in this communication, such as, for example, reducing consumption.
Microgeneration, distribution and forms of different distribution and projects that do not have to pass only by large structures and access to energy.
I believe that this would certainly contribute to greater financial transparency and make the plan cheaper.

Therefore, in addition to this political clarification and financial clarification, there is still a lack of discussion about what I believe to be an absolutely crucial point, which is the persistent tone placed on public-private partnerships as if they were the solution to everything.
When asked where the money comes from, tell us from the Commission that it comes from wherever it is.
I confess that I am not clearer when it is told me that money will come from somewhere without being told exactly where it comes from.

Therefore, this bet on public-private partnerships when we talk about low-carbon technologies is certainly something we can be sure of: if we do not know where the money comes from and knowing that these are public-private partnerships, we know at least who will pay.
Who will pay? Initially it will be the contributors, who incidentally are also consumers.
And we know that those who pay less are at the end the institutions and private organizations that make investments, they are rewarded by it but in the end they end up by maximizing profits.
And without this clarification, it seems that once again we are systematically passing on to future generations the bill for the changes in the European model.

The European Union recently celebrated in the area of World Trade Organization an agreement with Latin American countries, where it committed to reduce substantially and progressively the tariffs on banana imports from those countries.

Please note that such an agreement will have a direct negative impact on European banana producers, particularly those in Portugal (Madagascar), and also, to a greater extent, on Spanish canary island producers.

I would like to remind you that the situation of the farmers in these regions is already seriously complicated by the physical and geographical characteristics of the islands and the size of their explorations, which leads them to face permanent difficulties that penalize their development.

It is therefore urgent to take measures in defense of banana producers, wood producers, and canary breeders, taking into account the serious and immediate impact that the new agreement with Switzerland has on the European market for imports and consequently on the production and marketing of bananas from these outermost regions.
Thank you Mr President, colleagues, Commissioner. As rapporteur for the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs I would like to start by saying that
To congratulate Mr. Krilov, even in his forced absence, and to highlight the way in which he prepared this important report, facilitating the main objective.
I would also like to congratulate Ms. Creel for her presentation.
The main objective is to make procedures simpler and speed up the implementation of programmes financed by the Cohesion Fund, the Structural Funds and the Regional Development Fund.
In the context of the current financial, economic and social crisis, the pressure on national financial resources has been increasing.
This pressure will decrease with better use of EU funding, with faster access to these resources for those most affected by the economic crisis.
More than twenty million Europeans are unemployed, which means that there are more than four million more people than a year ago, and unfortunately, the trend is increasing.

This situation demands that we ensure the proper execution of cohesion programmes given that they represent the most powerful and relevant tool for supporting the real economy, particularly in small and medium-sized enterprises and employment.
SMEs are the engine of the European economy and the actors of sustainable growth and job creation in quantity and quality.

The continuation of simplification and clarification of the rules that govern cohesion policy will undoubtedly have a positive impact on the pace of programme execution, particularly because it will be possible to:
National, regional and local authorities should consider the possibility of clearer and less bureaucratic rules that would allow more flexibility in adapting programs to new challenges.
Of course, this crisis was an unexpected crisis, and of course the principle of precaution had to take priority.
But there are lessons to be learned, and the first one is that during five days we did not hear a European voice sufficiently strong and responsible politically.
And that voice was missing in what concerns the defense of passenger interests, the clarification of their rights, the search for alternative transport solutions, and the coordination of solutions.

A second conclusion is that the exit from the crisis cannot appear to the common citizen as a game of power between those who want to avoid losses and those who want to defend the principle of precaution.
There must be transparency and objectivity in the terms on which we exit a situation of total failure in European space.
Therefore, improvement of scientific tests and coordination at a European level are also necessary.

Thank you Mr President. I too would like to start by congratulating the work and persistence of Mr TICAI in this so important debate and for the work he has done on improving the energy performance of buildings and towards a more sustainable Europe.
Energy consumption in the European Union is significantly higher than what is acceptable, which is why moving forward with proposals of this nature is so important.
It is time for us to have an ambitious European policy and add complementary measures, especially in the crisis situation we are living in.
The construction sector has been considered one of the sectors with the greatest potential in terms of the economy and energy, but this is not all.
And it is not just that, which is why it is an excellent sector for setting public policies, and it is in this sense that I would like to conclude, Mr President.
We must therefore take this opportunity to invest in energy efficiency improvements for buildings and their potential to create millions of jobs over the next few years.
It is not just about new buildings but also about the rehabilitation and recovery of existing degraded or inadequate buildings.

Let us then take advantage of this legislation as a fundamental contribution to the revitalisation of the European economy and we must not continue to squander investment which can and should be strategic for recovery from the crisis. We expect investment from the Commission and we expect Member States to make use of that investment.

Thank you, Mr President, Mr Barroso, Commissioner, distinguished colleagues. I would like to start by congratulating Mr Manders on the work carried out in this report, as well as thanking those colleagues who collaborated with him on this file.

The simplification and improvement of the existing regulatory framework, as well as the unification of all existing legislation into one single regulation on the naming and labelling of textile products, is in itself an important fact.

But in addition, this proposal will have a positive impact on private agents and public authorities, and it will also allow for the incorporation of new fibers developed, thereby encouraging innovation in the textile and clothing sector.
This revision will also highlight the transparency of the process for adding new fibers to the list of managed fiber designations.
There seems to be no doubt that the agents involved will benefit from this regulation.
We look forward to the textile industry benefiting from lower administrative costs and the possibility to sell new fibers more quickly.

On the other hand, the authorities of those Member States will not need to transpose the amendments to national legislation, which will make it possible to have a cost-effective economy for those Member States.
And consumers will have the guarantee that the fibers named experience specific characteristics, still benefiting from the fact that the new fibers arrive sooner on the market.
For European industry, it is important to introduce these new fibers as a way to promote innovation, increasing equally the level of information provided to consumers.
In today's context of a globalized world, emerging economies with increasingly large markets in which billions of products produced by millions of companies circulate.
The speed at which innovation reaches consumers is absolutely crucial for companies, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
The application of this regulation may have increased its competitiveness.
These small and medium-sized enterprises will certainly gain with this new market share regulation and, thereby, contribute to employment growth in Europe.
The scarcity of organs for transplantation is a major problem.

It has been mentioned several times already, but it is a major problem that poses questions related to public health as well as issues associated with strengthening the parallel market and organ trafficking, which in no way strengthens our healthcare systems or citizens.

Therefore, we have to combat this crime and fight it through proposals such as those we are discussing here. It seems to me to be more important and more relevant than ever before, which is why I want to focus on the dimensions and issues raised by these two proposals.
The current system we have in place, which does not include these two proposals, is one that is fraught with huge inequalities.
成员国之间的不平等，现有体系之间的不平等，获得机构机会的不平等，公民之间的不平等——在我看来，我们甚至似乎无法忍受这种不平等。

If we are talking about proposals that have as their basis and have as support issues such as adhesion, volunteerism, voluntary activity, please excuse me, gratitude, confidentiality, data protection.

Of course, we must guarantee all rights and conditions, but it is very important that we go beyond the limited circle of the conventional family, otherwise this would be just another form of inequality.

Therefore, promoting eHealth as the main source of data and producing patient data and security seem to me more than sufficient reasons for all of us to be together tomorrow morning and vote in favor of these two extremely important proposals.
The ability to replace damaged human organs with those from another person, preventing their rejection, is one of the great successes of modern medicine.

The European benchmarking reveals that medium-sized countries such as Portugal qualify very well in such comparisons, and larger countries like Spain are now recognized as leaders in organizational and good practice.
There are some principles and practices to be saved.

Finally, Madam President, ensure equal access to transplants for all those who need them and for whom they qualify according to harmonised clinical criteria, respecting the principle of universality of access to healthcare, a paradigm of European social policy that we should be proud of.
I congratulate the rapporteurs on their work.
I would like to emphasize that it is with great satisfaction that the European People's Party and the Portuguese Members of the European Parliament have expressed their support for this initiative.
European Union has initiated the process of acceding to the European Convention on Human Rights.

We consider that this aspect from a technical, legal and political point of view is fundamental because Parliament is also it a house of human rights and a house where human rights have great relevance and I wanted now just to note what we considered very important.

These members of the European Council are being sent a signal that the European Union is reinforcing its commitment to their situation and to democratic standards and respect for fundamental rights.
Social housing is an economic service of general interest with an important role in the market, creating positive externalities for the benefit of all society.
According to Protocol No. 26 annexed to the Treaty of Lisbon, it is up to national, regional and local authorities to execute and organize this type of service.
Therefore, it is not understandable that this restriction on public aid should apply to families with incomes below EUR 30 000.

It refers to a poverty measurement that is done in absolute and purely financial terms, which does not take into account the diversity of the 27 Member States. Summarizing it as a simple solution argument.
The social housing responds to cultural, social questions, proximity to work, important redefinition of the role of women in the market, mobility of workers in the European space.

Economic and cultural integration, and the need for its integration, even with the risks of ghettoization associated with it, which we must combat with due balance.
Is the Commission not encroaching on the competence of the Member States?

Let us take this opportunity, Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, to highlight the fact that we are debating the first report from the start of the Agriculture Commission under the new ordinary legislative procedure provided for by the Treaty of Lisbon.

This is an historic moment that, by confirming in this Chamber the sense of vote I am proposing, will give the best possible start to this new period of shared competences in agriculture in the European Union.

In the spirit of active solidarity, with respect for the specificities and differences of its parts, as the only viable path for the construction of our common European project.

I would like to thank Mr Cioloş and other high-ranking Commission officials with whom we have worked and negotiated the openness and flexibility demonstrated.
The Spanish Presidency of the Council also made every effort to make our desire for an agreement at first reading a reality.

This thank you is naturally extensive to the shadow rapporteurs from other political groups as well as to the excellent staff of the secretariat of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development of this Parliament, whose collaboration made it possible to reach a result which I consider very positive.

I would also like to highlight the decisive contribution made by the Federation of Sugar Farmers and by the regional and national governments in the way they became involved and worked towards obtaining a solution for sugar beets.

The presentation of the Council proposal on October 2nd in the Committee on Agriculture took place at a time when there were no prospects at all for the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, which continued to await ratification by all Member States.
In this context, the initial idea of the Commission and the Council was that the proposal should be approved in a simplified procedure with no changes at all so as to take effect from 1 January 2010.

With the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, and despite the dominant opinion expressed by other political groups, as well as by the Council and the Commission, that the proposal should continue in simplified procedure because they believed that

The proposed draft did not require changes and should enter into force quickly. Although I have expressed my opinion, you and the Group of Socialists and Democrats understand that the Parliament should already pronounce itself within the scope of the Treaty of Lisbon, assuming its role as colegislator.

We did it on time, because from there on new possibilities opened up, first with the contribution of the Committee on Regional Development and the support of Mr Nuno Teixeira, whom I thank very much indeed.

'Congratulate and thank you for the cooperation always given in this process, and then with my report introducing new possibilities for sugar in beet as well as with the contribution and support of colleagues from the Agriculture Committee.'

Finally, in this first intervention, I would like to say that when we come to the proposed changes by the Commission, which were voted on in the Committee on Agriculture and supported by myself, we have not been able to accept them within the compromise obtained in the trialogue.

It was essential to reach an agreement in the first reading, respecting the improvements already achieved and the need for entry into force so as not to compromise its retroactivity from January of this year.
However, as the Commission is already preparing a revision of the PSE, we will certainly have the opportunity to debate this in the near future.

Ladies and gentlemen, we are facing an acceleration of a global change that has a devastating impact on our economic, political, and social systems, resulting in devastating consequences for all our citizens.
We have witnessed an unprecedented weakening in the ability of states to respond.
The European Union has succeeded in identifying common causes and allies and acting clearly and unitedly on the world stage.
Extraordinary situations require joint action.

If we do not take the necessary strict measures and collective responsibility, Europe will be voted out of minorization and poverty, and only a strong, respected Europe that abides by its common rules can respond adequately to the new times.
The translation of the Portuguese speech into English is: 'Weak and debt-ridden states do not have the capacity to protect their citizens.'
Therefore, we need to regain the confidence of citizens, win the battle for stability, budgetary rigor, job creation, monetary union stability, globalization, and strategic choices.
This is subject to our having our future committed.
And win the future by betting on social cohesion, ensuring peace, and building a new model based on values of freedom, social justice, and responsibility.
Thus, the strategy 2020 and the integrated guidelines Europe 2020 constitute essential tools for a new cycle of growth and employment in Europe.
For correct implementation and achievement, it is necessary that quantifiable and clear objectives be set in employment, education, and poverty reduction.

It is also decisive for the success of the strategy that everything be done to facilitate the transposition by the Member States of their national objectives and to ensure correct implementation of this strategy.
When the Economic and Monetary Union completed ten years, the Commission considered the euro the most successful project of the Union.
We would have difficulty in stating it without limitations today, because the crisis has shown beyond doubt that the Economic and Monetary Union is an unfinished project.
Minimum safety measures were taken in an emergency situation, but let's not be deceived. The pressure conditions, the direct interests of the major players...
The painful nature of the decisions and their slowness have weakened the image of the euro and the European Union among citizens and the world.
There is a need to address facts.
The European Union and the euro are an integration process, not just inter-country cooperation.
It is an unfinished process that at this time either strengthens or risks disappearing.
There are three issues that need to be addressed. Firstly, it is important to consolidate the instruments that were launched in this emergency climate. We need to create a fundamental

It is necessary to move forward with Eurobonds, it is necessary to advance with European supervision and regulation, and it is necessary to move forward with a European dimension in managing banking crises.
Second dimension, it is important to perceive that there is no strong growth if the economy is weak. The expected growth of 1% for the European Union is unsustainable in terms of
The strategy 2020 is nothing more than a collection of good ideas if there are no means of implementation.

Thirdly, Mr Olli Rehn, fiscal consolidation is important but it cannot exist alongside growing divergences between the Member States that make up the Union. The convergence policy must be urgently revisited. Thank you very much, Mr President.
Mr President, several members of the PPE Group have already given a very comprehensive summary of the situation.
I guarantee that it will now be necessary to refer to the role of national states.
In fact, national governments also have a role in this regard by imposing their requirements on their states.
The conditions under which the single currency can be strengthened and this project of monetary and economic integration can be taken forward.
And here I would like to say that our party, the party linked to the PPE, which is the PSD in Portugal, is supporting the government on the austerity measures because we consider that

The mistakes that throughout these fifteen years the social democratic government committed in Portugal, which unfortunately today everyone can see, those errors need to be repaired and they will have the support of the PSD to be repaired.

But if we are supporting austerity measures, we also criticise the Portuguese government and it is a good example for other similar cases because it is not reducing expenditure. And what is fundamental is that it is not just about

Increasing taxes to reduce the deficit but it is reducing expenditure, making the government have the courage to take measures that reduce expenditure, that reduce the deficit, that reduce public debt.
This applies to Portugal and other countries that are currently facing a difficult situation, and as European parliamentarians, we have a responsibility to also make an effort in our own countries.
Economic policy measures necessary to strengthen the euro and to make this area of integration, this dream that is a dream of the EPP and a dream of all of us, a reality.
Therefore, we criticize those governments that do not have the courage in their states to take the necessary measures.

Madam President, colleagues, I would like to start by saying that the report on the evaluation of the results of the 2016/2010 strategy for equality between men and women, which aims to influence strategies on this matter for the future, could in our opinion have been more assertive and less polemic.

In fact, the way in which several ethically sensitive issues have been addressed, namely the issue of sexual and reproductive health for women, should have been distinct if the aim was really to achieve the greatest possible consensus.

In times of normal economic growth, there is a significant concern about women's rights, particularly with respect to the gender gap in employment, society, and the family. However, these problems become much more profound during a social and economic crisis such as the one we are experiencing now.
There is therefore a need for a reinforced strategic commitment by the Member States at the level of local and regional entities and Community institutions with regard to protection.
In line with what has been said by President Dóla and Mr. Verheugen, it is essential that there be an EU economic government, but this economic government should be centred on the Commission.

This is the first point I wanted to highlight, and having said this, let me say that we should not just focus, as we have done all morning here, on our debate being focused solely on immediate issues, but
Also in those included in the strategy 2020. I would highlight in particular the issue of education and training for young people, the issue of innovation, research and development.

Because these are the gaps that will allow Europe to be competitive in the global space. And today I have to say that unfortunately, the European educational model failed. It failed because when compared with the emerging country models.

India, China and Brazil have now become less demanding and less strict models. Therefore, I also urge that there be rigor and demandingness in the context of European educational systems regarding this idea of innovation, development, research and education.
With that rigor and exigency, we will prepare our young people to compete in the global market.

We cannot think only about this year's crisis or the next two or three years; we must think about Europe's strategy over the next ten to twenty years, which depends on a rigorous and demanding education system.
Never has the European project, constructed with so much effort over the last 50 years, been under such threat.
The fraud committed by European citizens is enormous. The financial system that was supposed to serve them destroyed their savings, pensions, investment projects, jobs, and in short, their future.

In respect to the necessary strengthening of the entire financial services market – banking, insurance, securities, real estate – the path to follow is clear and resides in the architecture we are discussing today.
We need a European supervision architecture that covers all products and actors, which should be equipped with methodologies and tools.
Effective intervention and capable of responding to market reality, especially in the European context where there are no national borders.

The risk cannot and must not be eliminated from the financial market, but we need regulation that makes this risk more transparent and prevents the accumulation of bubbles whose explosion affects the entire system and paralyzes the real economy.

But despite these defenses, new crises occurring in the future it is crucial to dispose of mechanisms that limit the contagion, especially as regards the banking system, because this is vital for the functioning of the economy and the deposit of citizens' savings.

Here, exactly in the powers and competences of the banking authority, resides the capacity to execute a new strategy on the management of cross-border crises in the banking sector, which is the topic of my report.
It is not in our power to prevent bank failures, but we can ensure that their restructuring or potential liquidation is carried out in full compliance with all relevant laws and regulations.
In an orderly manner, limiting collateral effects on the rest of the system and above all avoiding it being contributing to paying the costs of crises that they generate.

For such a purpose, it is necessary a set of new devices; it is necessary to adopt rules, definitions, methodologies, instruments, and terminology common to all the interveners in restructuring, reorganization or liquidation operations.
It is necessary to harmonize the relevant national legal frameworks for crisis management, namely laws on insolvency and liquidation.
It is necessary to attribute extended intervention powers to supervisors.
It is necessary to draw up clear criteria, not only quantitative but also qualitative, which allow us to initiate interventions in an institution in difficulty.
It is necessary to prepare contingency plans.
The entire process for twenty seven Member States requires time.
Meanwhile, nearly 50 out of the 12,000 banks operating in Europe represent 70% of assets.
This implies a huge concentration of risk but also an opportunity to intervene primarily on them.

There are conditions for proposing a special and urgent process of finding banks that, due to their size and relationships with other banks, may have a possible systemic impact on the financial system.
For those banks, it is possible to anticipate special supervision by the new European banking authority, albeit operating within the College of National Supervisors.
It is possible and urgent that they, according to the risk they manage, start making contributions to a fund that finances eventual interventions.
It is important that the banking authority creates a specialized unit to coordinate interventions in case of difficulties in these banks.
In its entirety, the proposed elements ensure that interventions in systemically important transnational banks are consistent and coherent within the
Different countries and above all that principle so dear to Europe, that the costs of pollution caused by those banks should be borne by the polluter themselves.
This proposal fits perfectly with what we are discussing, especially as regards the powers of the banking authority. I would even say that this is the most evident test of its effectiveness.
In the case of the vote in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, there was a large majority in support of this proposal – 87% of the votes.
We also have a majority vote in this institution in favour of supporting this proposal, which is visionary, realistic but pragmatic. We
Let us take urgent action to restore Europeans' confidence in Europe's financial system, particularly its banking system.
Briefly, to highlight just four points.
The first one is that it was an extraordinary experience to work in such a solidarity with my colleagues from other political forces.
Thank you for including it in the supervision package, and thank you particularly to Mr. Garcia Margalho for all the collaboration that was possible to obtain.

In second place, I would like to thank my personal collaborators and also those colleagues who made contributions to the specific report that is now in my charge, which has allowed me to incorporate 90% of their proposals.
A special word for the secretariat, for Susana Vrabova, and for the Commission services.

Finally, my words of thanks to the Commissioner, for his services and for expressing in a very clear manner the hope that, indeed, over and above the report which I hope will be adopted tomorrow, it will be possible to build a solid foundation, a truly European foundation that protects citizens.
Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner. I would also like to start by thanking the rapporteurs for their excellent work.

Deforestation, as we know, is one of the main environmental and social problems on the planet, and each year we lose 3 million hectares of forest, contributing thus to 20% of global carbon emissions and representing an enormous threat to biodiversity.

The contribution of deforestation to climate change is undeniable, and as such it is very responsible for the occurrence of extreme weather events and even for desertification of vast areas on the planet.
The loss of biodiversity puts all humanity at risk, but that risk and impact are not evenly distributed among us.
The communities with fewer resources and those that rely more on the forest's productivity to survive are the most affected.
Deforestation refers to our collective existence, natural resources scarcity, distribution, local communities' rights, and indigenous peoples'. It also relates to social justice.
The main cause of deforestation is illegal logging, which represents 20% to 40% of global industrial wood production.
Therefore, we are also talking about wealth transfer from producer countries to consumer countries of this same raw material.
This practice is illegal and puts at risk the sustainable exploitation of timber and the companies that engage in it.
It is not enough to have beautiful words.
This Parliament should adopt strong and effective measures in this struggle.
This report takes a very significant step in that direction by defining the prohibition of trade in Madeira.
In Belgium also good intentions are not enough.
Effective means are needed, namely sanctions which in this case could be of three types.

Firstly, the deceptions that are removed from the economic benefits of illegal practices, aggravated by recurrence. Secondly, the seizure of the raw materials of the products in question. Thirdly, the immediate suspension of the authorization to exercise a commercial activity.

And that is because whoever explores or commercializes a natural resource should be socially responsible, and also, whoever first puts wood or wood products on the European market should be required to take care to ensure that it comes from legally harvested timber.
Therefore, all subsequent operators should provide basic information about this wood, namely its origin and destination.
The people must still have the right, and I finish here Mr President, the right to receive information on who complies and who does not comply. Thank you very much.
Europe needs to renew confidence and hope.
In a crisis that has already passed, we had the firefighters, as Jacques Delors said.
We hope that the Belgian Presidency will attract architects.
The first test naturally will be in September, when the Council gets closer to Parliament's proposals on financial architecture.

However, one of Europe's biggest challenges today is to ensure that the European currency does not decline, whether due to lack of accompanying instruments, lack of growth in the euro area, or above all, increasing divergences and internal tensions caused by the economies that comprise it.
Cutting structural funds as proposed by the Commission, which were created to stimulate convergence in divergent economies, seems to be setting fire to a not yet extinguished fire.
We clearly need architects.
One last question I would like to ask is about the external dimension of EU action, in particular, learning more about what the Belgian Presidency has proposed for Cancun and for Doha.

This initiative report that we are debating today on the responsibility of the JH should be congratulated for the way it was conducted and for its final good result. It is absolutely essential in this time when there is a need to
Agricultural policies increasingly focus on markets, farmers in Europe face very low income levels, and millions of consumers affected by the crisis require affordable food prices at all times.
Therefore, if farmers' income increasingly depends on market values generated, and the price of food depends on its good performance, then improving the functioning of the food supply chain.
It becomes absolutely necessary in order to achieve a fairer distribution of wealth from agricultural producers to final consumers, ensuring fair returns for some and adequate prices for others.

For this purpose, it is necessary to rebalance the relationships that are established along the food supply chain, giving them transparency, ensuring the existence of good practices in a fair and competitive manner.
In this regard, we support the Commission in taking account of the proposals broadly supported in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development.
A few days ago, all the workers at a shoe company in Ericeira, Portugal were fired after receiving a simple text message with no further explanation.
Please bring this case here because unfortunately it is a flagrant example of the abuse of collective dismissals in Europe.
It goes against all European rules and shows no common sense, respect, or dignity.
There have been nine million new unemployed people in Europe since the crisis began, out of a total of twenty five million. How many have been fired in such a shameful way as this?
I would say it increasingly unhappily.

Dear Mr President, dear Commissioners, distinguished colleagues, after four consecutive years of reduction in unemployment rate from 2004 to 2008, the current economic crisis has cancelled out many of the progress achieved.

The information must be reliable, validated by independent authorities, accessible, and directed towards a non-specialized public.

The silence period granted to the European Agency should be extended from 60 to 120 days.
The requirement of a foundation of neutrality reinforces the contradictory and balances the final result.
The EMA has an essential role as a privileged source of objective information.

Legislative on economic governance but not at the expense of speed, putting quality second.

The President of the Commission cannot be an ex-officio member of the Council.
This is what we need to present to European citizens.

The resolution of this crisis, this serious crisis that Europe and the European Union is experiencing, can only be achieved through deepening economic governance and the Community method.

There is no doubt in our minds that more Community method, more economic government, and the instruments proper for a single true currency in the euro area are the means by which this crisis can be faced and overcome.
