The Community method to introduce the economic government, giving the single currency the conditions necessary for it to triumph over the European crisis.

It is with this that we count and with its manifest adherence to European ideals, Mr President, that you are going to break it.
Thank you Mr President. I would like to start by congratulating Ms Luhan and Mr Manesco on their outstanding work on their respective reports.
Both constitute an important contribution to the ongoing discussion on the new cohesion policy for 2014-2020.
Today more than ever, achieving economic, social and territorial cohesion is essential for Europe's competitiveness at a global level.
This goal will only be achieved if we are conscious that by strengthening and developing the regional dimension we can have a cohesive Europe inside and competitive outside.

In this particular, I would highlight three points that I consider crucial. Firstly, decentralisation, making sure that local and regional authorities, especially those with legislative powers, participate more and contribute to a better implementation of cohesion policy. Secondly, establish the.

Member States to invite regional and local authorities to participate in negotiations on the future of the Structural Funds on an equal footing with national authorities and representatives; and lastly, to strengthen the role of regional authorities in preparing, managing and executing programmes.
Only thus will the principle of subrogation be fulfilled with the greatest involvement of these authorities throughout the process.

Another aspect that I consider crucial is the suggestion of a simpler architecture for funds post-2013, not as a consequence of the economic crisis but as a general principle of future cohesion policy in order to facilitate the absorption of funds.
The great concern underlying the Treaty of Lisbon was to bring Europe closer to citizens.
Therefore, we should not only do this but also make his life easier by avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens that today discourage his participation.
Therefore, we will be able to achieve the objective of true territorial cohesion.
Therefore, we will reduce disparities within the EU, which are now starkly contrasting and with a huge gap between rich and poor regions.
More participation also means more responsibility, and this responsibility must be assumed and shared by all in order to achieve a stronger and more competitive Europe.
Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I would like to start by congratulating Edit Bauer and Mr Andor on their excellent work on this report.
The trafficking of human beings dishonours our society and requires a strong and coordinated response from everyone.

In Europe, where we signpost freedom of expression as a fundamental value.
The Europe we dream of does not hide behind military organizations that write their history with blood.

Thirdly, it consolidated the militarization of access to energy resources.
Finally, there is a military defense of the development model that generates environmental imbalances and disrupts social crises.
Therefore, I mean, in my opinion, with this summit we lose in democracy, we lose in freedom, and we lose so that some may gain at war.
The first point I wanted to make clear here, which is important to reinforce in this Parliament, is that
According to the media and some European leaders' statements, the euro has been fundamental in responding to the current crisis.

Without the euro, we would not be in this difficult situation with the high taxes on the weakest countries, a huge devaluation, and with the German mark possibly appreciating uncontrollably to cushion the German and European economies.
Therefore, the euro was a factor of stability especially not only for the countries which are in the euro area but also for the currencies of those countries which did not want to join the euro area.

And that is why we have to defend this community which has managed to respond to the crisis better than anyone else, and which we will see in future events, for example what will happen to the US dollar and the United States of America - we will see how the euro actually has advantages.

We now have the responsibility in this Council to do everything possible to defend the euro, specifically by establishing a stability fund that follows the Community method and is capable of introducing liability in the event of excessive debt.

Countries in a more fragile situation, which have fulfilled their obligations and have shown solidarity at least through their declarations made available externally, should be ready to show solidarity within the context of the European area.

Thank you very much, Mr President, to Mrs Sârbu for her excellent report, advising the Commission most strongly to take it into account, especially in those aspects where the complexity of agricultural issues greatly exceeds the strict dimension of A.
Agriculture requires the involvement of other areas such as competition in the internal market and financial regulation, as well as its treatment in other external fora such as the G20 or the EC.

The issues absolutely vital for agriculture, for farmers, and for ensuring sufficient quantity and quality food for Europe's and the world's populations can only be addressed if they are tackled in all their dimensions.

And the ambitious objectives of CAP reform can only be achieved if they transcend the strict boundaries of agriculture and their objectives were equally taken into account in the necessary interventions of other policy areas and other global organizations.
This report makes it clear, and I welcome it for that reason.

Thank you Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues. I want to start by thanking all the contributions that have been made on this report that Parliament has presented on Alzheimer's disease and other dementias.
We all know that the situation we are living in is substantially dramatic and still much underdiagnosed, as mentioned here.
I just want to refer to one issue that was prevalent in all interventions but probably not so highlighted, which is the dignity of patients, their rights.
And not only patients but also their families and those who take care of them, whether they be informal caregivers or professionals associated with these types of diseases.

I am content – and I say this quite honestly – with what the Commissioner has said, when he indicates that he shares the same concerns as the European Parliament, and that the European Commission sees very positively all the recommendations in the report presented by Parliament, and that it will do everything within its power to put them into practice.
We know that each day that passes is later than the previous one in this matter, which gives urgency to what we have in our hands.
Therefore, we also know that tomorrow Parliament will be voting on this matter.
We will wait for the result of the vote, but we know, Mr President, that European citizens expect much more from us than solidarity and moral comfort.

They expect us to take specific and adequate action. I hope, Mr President, that you will put this into practice, and that the Commission, which has an initiative on this matter that unfortunately this Parliament does not have, will put it into practice.

All that priority which you give to this domain and which transforms it into a legislative initiative so that citizens and their families see their rights respected and they receive equality and dignity that they deserve. Thank you very much.

In the first place, I would like to say that this Parliament, on the day we are discussing the Hungarian Presidency, without prejudice to being able to discuss all the issues it intends to address, should concentrate itself on the problems of the European Union, which is not what it is doing.

or aspects which are internal aspects of Hungary and which can be regulated in a sound and normal relationship between the European Commission and the Hungarian Government and Parliament.

Very bright and very ambitious Hungarian agenda for this semester, focusing on and prioritizing three matters that will be essential for Europe's future.

Solidarity with millions of Egyptian citizens who are in Cairo and throughout the country, suffering from hunger, oppression, unemployment.

Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner. I would also like to say that I think this issue is more important than ever for us to continue living in the deceit we have lived in Europe.

To deceive, to be false, that is what they want to call it, because we have been operating above all in matters of collection of dental crowns in military cordons, based on information that is deceptive.
We know, as has already been mentioned, that in Europe the collection of cervical cancer cells through the medical cord does not reach 50%.
And yet we also know that its possibilities for disease treatment may be invaluable. Diseases such as cancer, Alzheimer's, rare diseases – the possibilities are immense.

But what we left you was that something should happen, which established a group of private banks for the preservation of cells, telling parents and mothers that they could keep their children's cells and, from there on, at birth and from there on, take care of them in the future if necessary.
We should be more responsible than that because the probability of ensuring this happens is very low as we know.
And this false promise that has been sold to the parents costs money.
In Portugal, for example, it costs three minimum wages and half this false promise.
The solution clearly involves creating public banks with open doors, because it is only through public banks that we can ensure equal use and access.
Effective medical treatment and more research that is equal for all, not just using stem cells as a commodity or a business that is growing but which is only for some.
Therefore, I believe that solidarity, common sense, and impartial information are not ultimately things that can be classified as more demanding.
We do not have power to impose; we have to go to power to promote.
That is within our competences, I think we should do it in the name of equality.
The price of food reached its historic high, which is the seventh consecutive time it has increased.
There are several factors that can explain this increase, being that the first one is a short-term factor.
It has to do with the coincidence of bad weather conditions in some countries such as Russia and Argentina.
However, there are two structural factors, which are structural in nature, which is why I bring these two factors here.
The first has to do with the fact that some food producers and consumers who were exporters have become importers, as in the case of China.
The second relates to the fact that some large multinationals have been able to play their prices in their favor.
The example of cereals is very clear at this level: it is dominated by six large multinationals.
This situation places farmers in great uncertainty about food prices.
Therefore, Europe should return to doing what it has not done for some time, that is, protect its producers and consumers.
In a world where everyone resorts to protectionism and where multinationals manipulate prices, we cannot continue to remain indifferent.

Regrettably, over recent years we have witnessed an increase in the falsification of medicinal products in Europe.
According to EU data, one and a half million counterfeit medicine boxes are sold annually through the legal supply chain.
It is a criminal activity that represents a serious threat to European patients and to the European industry.
The objective of this directive is to prevent the introduction into the supply chain of counterfeit medicinal products and thus protect public health.

In the opinion I drafted, the following key points should be highlighted:

- The introduction of the definition of counterfeit medicine, clearly placing the emphasis on consumer protection.
- The application of devices for the control and traceability of medicines.

Security of medicinal products subject to prescription, responsibility of all actors in the distribution chain, and finally, application by Member States of sanctions and effective measures to deter this criminal activity.
I obviously want to thank all the comments that were made by all colleagues and all colleagues.

In this compromise, safeguards are guaranteed so that we can accompany the process, assess it, and have systematically information that allows us to verify if it is being properly implemented or not, adequately or not – that is what we need to make changes.

Thank you also to your support.

What is happening in Ireland, Greece, Portugal, Spain and Italy – and who knows how many other countries? Because this is an endless sequence. They are different situations between each one of these countries, but there are some common things.

We cannot accept this.

Mr President, I will start by saying that I fully support what was said by my colleague.

Natural and human-induced disaster prevention is of enormous importance and increasing significance, and the European Commission systematically presents us with a number of intentions of procedure and calendar.
But there is one very complicated problem as has already been mentioned.
The Solidarity Fund is an instrument that normally responds to these situations but it takes a very long time – nine months to one year – and this is after a disaster.
As also referred to, and I repeat, we will take as much time as necessary. The case of Madeira, which had a huge disaster a year ago, still has not received any support.
Will the Commission not be able to review its own funding procedure and model of financing?
How can we maintain a reserve fund to deal with situations that become increasingly chronic?
We do not know where it will happen, but we know that it will happen. These climate changes are here to stay.
Therefore, exception cannot always respond to a situation of regularity.
The concerns raised here in relation to prevention and response to disasters are of great sensitivity and utmost importance for our populations, which must not and cannot be overlooked.

We are talking about very sensitive situations that deal with people's security and their belongings, which often evoke strong emotions due to loss of lives, devastated families, and the devastation of entire workforces.

However, few of our demonstrations impress everyone in the media and make them sensitive, if we then go to sleep on the work that we should do so that such situations can be avoided, minimized or better assisted.

It is an issue where the European Union can better demonstrate its presence alongside its citizens, helping them prevent disasters, especially when these occur, and being there in their hour of need, when they are most vulnerable and face the greatest challenges.
I will respond with my whole heart, although I do not wish to turn this debate into a European Parliament debate on Portuguese politics.

Thank you Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues. I start by congratulating Mr Schwab for his persistence in negotiating this important agreement and also by complimenting everyone who collaborated with him on this report.

We aim to ensure not just a high level of protection for European consumers but also that European companies, whatever their size, can supply goods and services to consumers in all 27 Member States without unnecessary legal obstacles.

This new directive will end the fragmentation of legislation that has been detrimental to the participation of our companies in the cross-border market and will give a major boost to the internal market.
I highlight the new provisions regarding information to be provided to consumers, requiring that this information be clear, understandable, and made available in a timely manner.
It is also important that the burden of proof as to the conformity of information requirements shifts to the trader.

As regards contracts concluded at a distance, especially those concluded by telephone or over the internet, rules should be laid down and consumers should be protected by simple and effective mechanisms.
We are sure that, at the end of the institutional negotiations, the new directive will contribute to making the European Union more competitive and dynamic, as required by a global economy.

Thank you, Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Mr President of the Commission. Firstly, I would naturally like to compliment them on the results of the Council meeting of 24 and 25 March, notably the consolidation of the single market.

European, but much more than that, either by institutionalizing a European stability mechanism, or by the fact, let us say, of the Treaty of Lisbon, which already comes from the euro area of March 11th.

Stronger to face the next three or four months, and partly we would have mitigated the effects of the crisis that at this moment my country Portugal is living through, on which I also do not want to leave my word.

Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Füle, we are living through a historic moment that demands a firm and determined action.
As many of you, I experience a mix of hope, concern, and expectation when witnessing events unfolding in the Mediterranean basin.

I am, however, satisfied with the proactive stance that Parliament is preparing to adopt regarding the revision of the European Neighbourhood Policy, which I hope will lead to a greater EU presence in this area, not just as a payer but also as an active partner.
From the beginning, by affirming the absolute necessity to defend our fundamental values in our relations with neighboring countries.
We can no longer remain indifferent in the defense of democracy, nor of human rights, and even less so in the defense of social justice.

We can no longer prioritize short-term stability over the long-term interests of citizens and their unyielding defense of individual and collective freedom, with particular attention paid to women's rights.
In future, the Union has to privilege an approximation from bottom up in its foreign policy.
It is imperative that this happens.
Only maximum involvement of local communities and civil society will ensure maximum effectiveness in its implementation.

But I must express frustration. I regret that this Parliament and the Commission do not want to take this opportunity to differentiate between, once again, the Eastern Neighbourhood policy with those countries which potentially could become in the future our partners in the Union within the Southern Neighbourhood policy.
The challenge also lies in the Commission demonstrating the ambition that the current moment demands in its April review process – a policy of neighbourhood.
Customized to each state, with clear benefits and a careful evaluation that allows us to move towards a future Mediterranean economic space with the new Southern democracies.

In conclusion, Mr President, Commissioner, we trust that the good atmosphere and the cooperation that have characterised our work on this subject will lead to the European Parliament's permanent involvement in the planning and evaluation of this policy. Thank you very much.
The reports we debate and which today's rapporteurs congratulate reinforce the set of initiatives that aim at relaunching the internal market.

Consumer Protection Commission for the internal market to give priority to competitiveness and dynamism of the market, a fundamental pillar of the 2020 strategy.

I would like to add my voice to those who have expressed concerns about the low catches of fishermen, exacerbated by the historically high prices paid for fuels, particularly in recent months.
As has been said here, the cost of fuel has a major impact on the survival of our small and medium-sized fishing businesses, particularly affecting their already meager earnings.
This shameful increase in prison numbers is also bringing us profound negative effects such as reduced sea exits, misery earnings for fishermen, exacerbated by low prices paid at first sale.

There has been an increase in imports of third country aquatic products and fish to the European market, which has led to a consequent abandonment of activity due to financial difficulties, with more job losses.

Thank you Mr President. I would like to start by congratulating the rapporteur and everyone who contributed to achieving this work.

In times of severe financial, economic and social difficulties and painful austerity measures in some Member States such as my own country Portugal, it is tempting to retreat behind protectionist and nationalist attitudes.
This is a mistake.

The European response to the crisis should involve a genuine European government and economy that pursues sustainable growth, promotes job creation, develops the social market economy, and provides long-term responses with defined objectives that member states can identify with.
The exit strategy from the crisis needs to be financed with a sufficiently ambitious EU budget.

In order to avoid another sovereign debt crisis and the eurozone, there is a need for closer coordination in budgetary policies, as well as the creation of a system for the issuance of public debt securities and eurobonds.
In conclusion, it should be emphasized that in this difficult period, it is also necessary to maintain social protection levels, especially for vulnerable citizens.
It is customary to say that crises help to strengthen Europe.

The slow, improvised, reactive way in which the EU is reacting to the Greek crisis is aggravating the situation every day and is casting doubt on the EU and its fashionable currency.
Despite the problems in the euro area, which have resulted in obvious flaws in the construction of the single currency, today we focus on its most fragile points.

In order for the current crisis to result in the strengthening of the Union, it is necessary to have a strategic vision, as has been done in the past, which unfortunately neither the Commission nor the Council have known how to impart to the European programme and project.
This Parliament report gives us this vision: more Europe, not less Europe.
The European Parliament reminds that a single market and currency generate unbearable divergences between economies which have to be counterbalanced by specific policies.

The functioning of the euro requires a strengthened European budget with its own resources, it requires a European debt issuance agency that is solidarity-based and capable of protecting states from market speculation.
And provide them with credit at reasonable prices and terms still recognizes that diplomatic and mobility of workers between countries require mutual recognition of social rights and pensions.
Parliament has united to send clear messages. Let us hope that the Commission and the Council will heed them.

In this context, Europe faces four challenges: first, the creation of jobs; second, the need to develop itself to remain competitive.
After that, the sustainability of social security systems, and finally the difficulty in finding people with the right skills to fill job vacancies.
This report has a dual objective: first, to emphasize the need to act swiftly to eliminate competence gaps in Europe; second, to better anticipate the needs of the job market in terms of competences.

Several measures stand out for this purpose. Firstly, in order to ensure the availability of qualified manual labor, it is necessary to improve basic competencies as well as competencies in science, innovation, information technologies, and communication, as well as foreign languages.

In fourth place, we draw attention to the link that should exist between educational establishments and the needs of the job market.
The internship should be of quality and supervised by tutors in order to lead to employment and end abuses related to the trainee situation.
Social partners and social dialogue are also given particular emphasis.

One year ago we witnessed the tragic combination of a earthquake, a tsunami and a nuclear industrial accident all in succession.
Today we pay a fitting tribute to the many thousands of victims of Fukushima.
The rare victims are those who tell us that they have learned a lesson; we must learn how to deal with natural disasters. With nuclear accidents, we have an obligation to avoid them.

One year after Fukushima, and new nuclear power plants continue to be built.

Fukushima obliges us, for all this, to reopen a debate that should never have been closed: the debate on nuclear energy.
A year ago, nuclear energy was unquestionable for the Japanese; today, two-thirds of日本人 do not want it.

There are currently 320,000 refugees in Japan, out of which 100,000 will never be able to return home.

The one who chose to include in its development model a mortal technology.

Diabetes affects more than 30 million people in Europe.

It is the result of collective work and it is a work that does not nullify the work done until now on chronic diseases, but rather reinforces and strengthens this ability we have to intervene collectively.

We have approximately 325,000 deaths per year associated with diabetes because we know that diabetes is the leading cause of, for example, heart attacks, strokes, amputations, failures of vital organs.
We have two options in my understanding.
The first one is to say that it is not so serious, that we can live well with this, and that each government should take care of itself.
The second is to say that the absence of a European strategy in this area is part of the problem.
I understand that from this side we have much to do.
We have much to do in early diagnosis, coordination, investment in research.
This resolution has the value of a beginning and of working together in this sense.

Thank you Mr President. I would like to start by congratulating Mrs Neubauer on her excellent work and noting the coincidence that we are celebrating Europe Day today, as we discuss and tomorrow adopt measures which address the legitimate concerns of our citizens.

The subject of this regulation is to impose limits on mobile phone charges levied on European consumers when they are roaming, with its main objective being to end roaming in the European Union by 2020.
Our citizens will benefit from an increased discount on prices in connection with calls to the SMSC and data services.
If there are operators who charge three euros per megabyte, as of July, the maximum price they can charge is twenty cents per megabyte, increasing this value to twenty cents in 2014.
As for calls received, the maximum price that can be charged this year will be eight cents, and five cents in 2014.
In July 2012, a family with two mobile users will save, as the Commissioner said, 200 euros on their bill.
Second benefit: greater quality information for consumers.
Since summer, operators have been required to inform consumers about prices when they travel outside the European Union.
So far, the obligation was only for within the European space.
Third advantage: the possibility of more operators entering the market, which means increased competition that will stimulate better services and lower prices.
Eventually, in the near future, consumers will be able to have two contracts, one for national services and another for foreign services, keeping the same mobile number and having just one bill.

Madam President, in February 2009 this Parliament adopted a report which supported the proposal from the European Commission to relaunch the European economy.
Clean energy projects, transport, new technologies, innovation – that was already where the European Investment Bank and the Structural Funds started to play their part.
More than three years have passed. We were able to produce the SICP, the Euro Plus Pact, the Fiscal Pact, the TSCG. All of them full of discipline, reinforced sanctions.

But in the meantime, while unemployment, especially among young people, reaches alarming levels, the European economy goes into recession and more than seven of its member states are experiencing negative growth.
Meanwhile, as Greece is no more than the first stone that threatens to bring down the castle, the relaunch agenda seems to have been forgotten.
This agenda is clear at this moment.
What matters now is not to attribute an urgency character to it anymore, but an emergency character in a situation which threatens to explode.
It is necessary to intervene urgently on several pillars.
Firstly, it is necessary that such a European Marshall Plan be constructed with growth-enhancing investment, employment creation, and convergence.
Project bonds are one of the possible channels.
In second place, it is necessary to stabilize interest rates with which countries finance.
Let us at least prepare ourselves to coordinate sovereign debt issuance and manage together the accumulated debt.
Third point: The European stability mechanism and the European Central Bank have to be prepared to actually function as true firebreaks in defense of European sovereign debt.
In fourth place, the credit which was emphatically transferred by the European Central Bank to the commercial bank must reach the companies.
One billion euros is being withheld in the banking system while thousands of viable businesses die every day due to lack of financing.
Fifth point: Without a search, investment does not make sense.
Weaker economies are being drained by austerity plans.
Are the strongest economies supposed to be allowed to pursue their internal affairs?

It is that almost 80% of transactions take place within Europe and it is up to the Commission, Mr Olli Rehn, to make recommendations directed not only at the weakest economies but also at the most dynamic ones.

There has to be an end to the positive style of discussion, dialogue and lack of accountability that high-ranking officials use to decide the fate of millions of European citizens and democratic institutions of member states. Thank you very much, Mr President.

Thank you, Mr President. I would like to start by congratulating the rapporteur on this report.
It deals with an issue of utmost importance for Europe.
In an era when we are experiencing a severe economic, financial, and social crisis, protecting intellectual property rights and combating counterfeit products is essential for the European economy.
This protection should enhance research performance and promote innovation; it should ensure scientific and technological knowledge, contributing to the development of new products and services.
All this in order to generate growth and create quality jobs.

Unfortunately, in recent years we have witnessed a significant increase in intellectual property violations in Europe, representing annual losses – as has already been mentioned – of 250 million euros for companies and the destruction of 185,000 jobs in the European space.

But in addition to these negative effects on the European economy, the violation of these rights also constitutes an equally serious threat to the health and safety of European consumers, since many falsified and counterfeit products such as foodstuffs, cosmetics, medicines, etc.
Etcetera are produced in unregulated environments.
Therefore, the customs authorities of the European Union play a crucial role in preventing the entry into the internal market of counterfeit products.
The revision of the current regulation aims to reinforce the control of the application of the legislation in question, to enhance the legitimacy of its intervention, and to increase the
Clarity of legal rules adapting to new realities and developments, thereby contributing to better protection of the economy and European consumers.
Intellectual property rights are thus a crucial priority in order to achieve the objectives of the 2020 strategy, with a view to achieving intelligent, sustainable and inclusive growth.

The election of a new Egyptian president in the post-Mubarak era is good news, but we must not delude ourselves that these presidential elections do in any way reflect the transition process that is taking place in Egypt.

It was well mentioned that the dissolution of the parliament days before the presidential elections poses several risks above the average, and in this case, the power concentrated in the Supreme Council of the

The armed forces were minimal and exaggerated; they have legislative power, reducing the powers of the President; in addition, they still have in their hands the definition of changes in the Constitution.

All this raises some concerns and should raise some concerns because Egyptians risk becoming spectators to military power and a return to the past with the lack of a fundamental element, which is a democratically elected parliament.
It is not for us to make changes in Egypt; it is for the Egyptians themselves.
But I think we Europeans have to be alongside all the changes that propose the restoration of what? The legitimacy of democracy and a democratic parliament elected by the people.

The future common fisheries policy must privilege its environmental, economic and social sectors.

I agree with the European Commission's position on the need to adjust this policy and specific measures that must take into account the disparities in the fishing and horticulture sectors in various coastal regions.

This policy places emphasis on regionalisation as a form of governance through increased participation by various stakeholders in order to enable a more appropriate response in the future to the needs and sensibilities of each maritime basin.

I proposed protection for the fragility of my region by proposing that the exploitation of its resources be carried out taking into account scientific data, giving priority to our coastal communities in their exploitation and restricting external access to within 20 miles of existing fishing banks.
To safeguard the fishing capacity of our important fishing communities, rejecting proposals for transferable quotas.

Proposed that our communities have better intervention in their affairs, fishing with the creation of a regional advisory council more suitable for peripheral regions, and I hope that we can thus have a better future.

Bank supervision also passes to be of the responsibility of the European Union. However, if everything goes wrong, and if banks were to fail, the responsibility for paying this failure would continue to be that of the national contributors, it would continue to be a national responsibility.

And lastly, I would like to briefly refer to the fact that we continue to restrict monetary policy to what should be a secondary issue in our current context – inflation, rather than employment creation and growth as it should be.

The leaders in Europe continue to insist on budgetary discipline. And I say 'budgetary discipline' because if we talk about it, then let us talk about it. What exactly are we talking about when we talk about budgetary discipline?

In my understanding, budgetary discipline means respecting the contracts with pensioners and not abandoning them with half-promises; in my understanding, budgetary discipline means respecting the contracts of those who work and not inventing extraordinary taxes or cuts in subsidies. Budgetary

The budget must respect the compromises on health, education, culture, and not close down services or cancel projects halfway through. Discipline means bringing banks under control and not removing contributors' money to save their banks.
This is an economic discipline that I would like to see implemented in the European Union, and we should not continue with this market celebration.

The budget currently under discussion in Portugal, with the Troika at its helm, is a prime example of this. It violates every single commitment that any country should have with its citizens not to violate the agreements made behind closed doors between Europe and its member states.

Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is a privilege to present the report on the twenty concerns of citizens and businesses.
In relation to the functioning of the single market, specifically in this debate with Commissioner Barnier marking the 20th anniversary of this market.
The first word to express gratitude to colleagues from all political groups, and especially to the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs for their constructive contributions and positive attitude.
It was a pleasure to work with everyone, and the report greatly benefited from our joint effort.

We know well and are proud that over the past two decades, the single market has been the driving force behind significant economic and job opportunities in Europe, transforming the lives of European citizens and European businesses alike.
Travel, residence, and work in the EU space are freedoms available to all citizens of the 27 member states.
For European consumers, the single market means more choice and lower prices.
For our companies, the single market means more business opportunities, with access to 500 million consumers, which means more economic growth and more job creation.
To illustrate the progress made by the single market in Europe since its creation in 1992 until the onset of the crisis in
2008 was enough to focus on the 2.7 million jobs created and the 2.3% additional growth of GDP.
Today, it is 13% cheaper to have a X-ray or be examined with an X-ray when you are travelling in Europe than it was in 2005.
The freedom of movement of people is most eloquently expressed in the ERASMUS programme.
More than two and a half million students benefited from this European exchange education and mobility programme.
In the last five years, companies have also benefited from a 25% reduction in administrative charges due to single market legislation.
But one question arises – is everything going well in a single market?
No, not everything works well.
The economic and financial crisis that affects us has had negative repercussions on the functioning of this market.

Our citizens in some countries have been living with the drama of unemployment and being confronted with austerity measures. They have developed a skeptical view of Europe and a negative attitude towards the internal market.
People still do not know or do not fully understand their rights, nor do they know where to find information or help.
On the other hand, many Member States unjustifiably delay the transposition of European Union Directives and legislation on the single market, thereby impairing its full potential.

In certain areas of citizens' daily lives, things as simple as, for example, the reimbursement of medical expenses after a temporary stay in another EU country, the opening of a bank account for an Erasmus student,

The act of changing the energy supplier, transferring pensions on retirement, recognizing qualifications, and the rating of a vehicle in another Member State are still very complex, difficult or costly acts.
It is important to respond to these problems.
This was my concern as rapporteur.
Therefore, the message written in the report is very clear: it is necessary for there to be much more political will from the Member States and European institutions.

'council, especially the council and commission, to better and jointly govern. It is necessary to regain the confidence of people and businesses, and it is necessary to facilitate the exercise of their rights.'

Madam President, Commissioner Barnier, dear colleagues, Regina Bastos, my congratulations on your efforts which have already been so successful.
When Jacques Delors was in charge of the European Commission, the single market was created in 1992.
Delaour synthesised then the three basic principles of the single market: competition that stimulates, cooperation that strengthens, and solidarity that unites.
Twenty years ago, the economic and financial crisis brought back the threat of national protectionism, and it became clear that the internal market was not yet finished.
The celebration of these twenty years has to be an opportunity for a relaunch of the single market, with the concern of putting the market at the service of citizens and not vice versa.
For this, it is necessary to define priorities, and I would like to talk about one in particular.
It is essential to have a common policy for producing and distributing energy at affordable prices for consumers with a high level of energy efficiency.
Through the European energy market, served by cross-border infrastructure with the possibility of a Community-scale investment representing added European value.
In energy as well, Madam President, we will judge the common market.
The major achievements of the European Union, which surely represents one of the strongest pillars of the development of the Union, its Member States and their regions.
Therefore, in order to be effective and fair, it is necessary to emphasize its policies in terms of equality among citizens and all regions, promoting internal cohesion within the Union.
In this context, it is essential to acknowledge that we can achieve greater development in our outermost regions through their fuller integration into the single market.

The regions such as Azores need to continue increasing their competitiveness by improving their competitive conditions, but we will never succeed if we do not solve our accessibility problems in the areas of transport.
We can achieve this through specific instruments that better respond to the problems posed by our isolation.
Therefore, we believe that the Commission should consider the POSEI transport scheme as an essential tool for integrating these regions into the internal market.
Madam President, I would like to begin by saying thank you very much for this excellent debate.
It was a very constructive debate and it was a debate that demonstrated that the single market is really a great achievement of the European project.
I welcome the presence of Mr. Mavrogiannis and his participation in this debate. I thank all colleagues for their constructive approach, some of which was somewhat critical, but understandable.
Thank you very much to Mr Barnier for his commitment and enthusiasm in discussing these issues, these problems of the internal market, and for the political will to resolve them.
We have much yet to answer to citizens.
Citizens are unhappy, they feel betrayed, and they expect more from us, more from the Council, more from the Commission, more from the Member States.
This balance is very useful; this balance of twenty years is important, but as many have said here, it is important to open the door to look at the future.
The future looks bright with many issues addressed here and with many measures already announced by the European Commission.

Therefore, it is important that the single market be one of the responses to the great challenge of competitiveness, employment, and economic growth.

The Gozze report, together with the report we will be drafting on the annual growth prospects of the EU at the end of this year, which will include the Spring Council, are two key elements of what is known as the European Semester.
This report covers the recommendations made by each member country to the Council on the basis of a proposal from the Commission. These recommendations outline, as has been said, with the

The European Central Bank (ECB) and the future European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB), an extraordinarily strong body that reinforces European control over economic policy and budgetary policies of member states.

The balance between control and autonomy at national level is not easy to find, and it has fallen to a level of imposition, mainly of discipline, and ultimately may even originate from a serious package of sanctions.

On the subject of the CFP, I would like to comment briefly that it is important for the Council, which is currently absent here, to give its negotiating mandate to its negotiators in a way that is consistent with the ambition to conclude quickly this TFTP package.

But more European coordination means less national control over their own destiny, which in turn requires a subtle balance but also an increased demand for quality in the recommendations made to countries in at least three or four dimensions.

Firstly, it is important to ensure consistency between medium and long-term objectives which include growth, employment and real convergence, and short-term recommendations focused above all on discipline and nominal convergence. Secondly, it is necessary that there be consistency

The conclusions that should be drawn from the analysis on macroeconomic imbalances, particularly on the asymmetric impact of common policies and negative externalities, the spillover effects of some national policies on other countries, are as follows.

I will be brief, Madam President. I just wanted to thank Mr Gosztics for his willingness to collaborate and to hope that he goes further in this spirit in order to broaden the consensus on his report. Let this spirit also prevail in what he says about the next.
It is true that there are many things we do not know about the action of xylanases.
But there are also many that we already know and it would be convenient not to forget them.
For example, we know that every extraction of bitumen uses more than 19 million liters of potable water, which would be enough to supply the drinking needs of 10,000 European citizens per year.

We also know that every single gas extraction from each operation is dumped on the ground, between thirty and three hundred tons, up to three hundred tons of chemicals, and nearly eighty percent of which remain on the ground and do not leave there.

We also know that in every extraction of X gases, radioactive elements and heavy metals are released underground, together with the evaporation of toxic residues resulting from the process, which constitutes an effective threat to public health.
This is a danger of water contamination from pollution sources, which is a real and imminent threat.

Knowing this, we know that also the extraction of gas from shales is an answer that appears to be easy, which only thinks in the short term, in industry and in profit, ignores populations, the future and the environment.

But this is also Europe that knows, in this House, that water is an essential resource, vital and important, which it knows how to protect citizens' health and which it must protect, which seeks to conclude agreements to avoid emissions and to actually propose energy efficiency, because we know that environmental standards are important, environmental and health standards.
Therefore, when one does not know everything, it is the minimum to be ignorant.
And they may even want to do it, but if they don't do it on our behalf, nor on behalf of the citizens who are here to represent us.
Ladies and gentlemen, in fact, the last few years have shown us that the Economic and Monetary Union has not resisted the crisis.
We should also show that we have a European institutional architecture full of gaps, particularly the European institutional architecture of the euro.
Therefore, the report and proposal presented here are so vague in terms of their position regarding that which is proposed by governments.
But also, as the rapporteur said, we are on a political choice, which is why I would like to clarify the reasons why we have some problems and cannot support this report.
Firstly, it has to do with issues related to conditionalities.

What we see and continue to have is a narrative in which there can be solidarity among different countries when everyone has complied with the stability plan and growth in terms of agreement on governmental pact for Europe.

More than one euro and a set of measures that do not impose anything other than massive doses of austerity in the periphery, as well as a set of recessionary measures that, as we have already seen, are not working.
A second reason has to do with banking union.
The rapporteur presents very well the banking supervision mechanism, but it is so necessary that we cannot avoid the essential, and the essential here is to continue to sum up the

'aglomerados sistemas nacionais', 'o que significa que estamos todos juntos na política bancária, estamos todos juntos na supervisão bancária, mas estamos todos separados quando algo correr mal e portanto continuarão os contribuintes a pagar.'
And a third point has to do with the common debt and issuance of Eurobonds.
Here again, we consider the possibility of issuing common shares, but only when it is already too late.

Because we need the debt as it is now, not just when there has been a correction of excessive debts, because with these policies that we are following they will never be corrected; on the contrary, they will become increasingly aggravated to the despair of an entire group of populations.

Therefore, Mr President, I want to finish by saying that despite all efforts, I believe we have here a very clear example of how, if we remain united but divided, we will surely fall. This is why it was important to go even further.
Ferreira, there has always been room for progress, but for Portugal, the support of the European Union over recent years has been essential.
Portugal transformed itself from a country where competitiveness was based on cheap labor to a highly skilled, highly prepared country.

Small-scale fishing should be entitled to special protection under the common fisheries policy, not just because it promotes social and economic cohesion and supports many families – which is a factor in the fixing of those communities along coastal areas.
Its economic and social sustainability should be an objective, ensuring us a differentiated fishing regime that gives priority access to resources.
Permitting proximity fishing and protecting the fishing rights enjoyed by those communities against transferable fishing rights.

Marine areas with reduced continental shelf and scarce resources concentrated in underwater mountains and fishing banks that should have protected access.

A financial point. The question that arises is as follows: do we want the European Union to make a difference in the context of the crisis, or do we want to aggravate the crisis?
Most European countries are now making huge efforts from a public finance perspective in order to overcome the crisis in a competitive manner and in such a way as to enable their countries to
The European Union, globally speaking, has great competitiveness and capacity for competition, but it is obvious that without investment there can be no growth and we cannot overcome this crisis.

Efforts will not be able to grow and fail this plan that we have accepted in all countries of the European Union with good accounts and prospects of growth and competitiveness.

The only and great instrument for this is just this multiannual financial framework, and therefore, if we want the European Union to be successful and its policy to be an example for other countries, we have to invest in the budget for financial perspectives.
